articles.description: Fixed: Favicon used as article image

articles.description:
Added: Resolve relative URLs in item link and media
Added: Item thumbnail fallback to channel thumbnail
Chore: Dependency updates
Thank you: @cpwnd
articles.title: v1.15.0

articles.description: Fixed: Several style issues
articles.title: v1.14.4

articles.description: style tweak
articles.title: v1.14.3

articles.description:
New: Adjust article grouping based on timezone. You need to add timezone in osmosfeed.yml for accurate grouping. See details in documentation.
New: Card title now toggles card content
New: all toggles on the UI are persisted with local storage. You can use it to track read/unread status within a single browser.
New: Build timestamp now links to the GitHub Action run
Changed: Sources are sorted based on publish time rather than alphabetical order
Changed: Style adjusted for easier reading
Fixed: Horizontal overflow on Safari
Fixed: HTML syntax error in default template
articles.title: v1.14.2

articles.description: git typo in gh run url
articles.title: v1.14.1

articles.description:
New: Adjust article grouping based on timezone. You need to add timezone in osmosfeed.yml for accurate grouping. See details in documentation.
New: Card title now toggles card content
New: all toggles on the UI are persisted with local storage. You can use it to track read/unread status within a single browser.
New: Build timestamp now links to the GitHub Action run
Changed: Sources are sorted based on publish time rather than alphabetical order
Changed: Style adjusted for easier reading
Fixed: Horizontal overflow on Safari
Fixed: HTML syntax error in default template
articles.title: v1.14.0: V1.14.0 (#79)

articles.description:
New: Thumbnail image display for each article
New: Improved color, spacing, and typography for easier reading
New: Click the date to toggle all accordions on that day. Ctrl + Click to toggle all accordions on the entire site.
Changed: All sections are expanded by default
Changed: Switched to vitest for easier testing
Fixed: Long string (e.g. URL) caused horizontal overflow
Thank you: @naari3, @tianheg

Thank you: @naari3

Added docs for Netlify deployment

Thank you: @sokomin, @molakirlee, @philippnagel, @tianheg

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
This is the best job I've had in my life and it's only possible because you keep showing up each day to read, learn, share, and discuss all-things-front-end (and a little CSS, of course) with us.
Thank You (2025 Edition) originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Thank You (2025 Edition)

articles.author: Daniel Schwarz
articles.description:
The text-decoration-inset property solves a problem that we‚Äôve had since the beginning of the web, which is that text decorations such as underlines extend beyond the first and last characters, resulting in vertical misalignment.
text-decoration-inset is Like Padding for Text Decorations originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: text-decoration-inset is Like Padding for Text Decorations

articles.author: Sunkanmi Fafowora
articles.description:
It's settled! A new CSS display property keyword called grid-lanes will trigger a masonry layout mode.
Masonry Layout is Now grid-lanes originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Masonry Layout is Now grid-lanes

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
Jelte Lagendijk built a Raycast extension for searching CSS-Tricks articles where you simply type and a get a solid set of real-time results.
Search CSS-Tricks Raycast Extension originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Search CSS-Tricks Raycast Extension

articles.author: Temani Afif
articles.description:
In this article, we follow up the work we did to create responsive rows of circular images in a previous article by arranging the images around a circle with a clean hover effect.
Responsive List of Avatars Using Modern CSS (Part 2) originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Responsive List of Avatars Using Modern CSS (Part 2)

articles.author: Daniel Schwarz
articles.description:
The best CSS news from around the web from the last two weeks. In this edition: advent calendars, CSS Wrapped 2025, and the latest Web Platform Updates.
What‚Äôs !important #1: Advent Calendars, CSS Wrapped, Web Platform Updates, and More originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: What‚Äôs !important #1: Advent Calendars, CSS Wrapped, Web Platform Updates, and More

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
Andy Clarke with a brand-new resource. It generates the sort of fun typography that Andy commonly uses in his own work that's geared towards cartoon headings.
Toon Title Text Generator originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Toon Title Text Generator

articles.author: Temani Afif
articles.description:
A list of rounded images that slightly overlap each other is a classic web design pattern. The main idea is not complex, but the new thing is the responsive part. that dynamically adjusts the overlap between the images so they fit inside the container.
Responsive List of Avatars Using Modern CSS (Part 1) originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Responsive List of Avatars Using Modern CSS (Part 1)

articles.author: Daniel Schwarz
articles.description:
How far can we really go with container queries? There are dozens of media queries now, so what if there were dozens of container queries as well? What could we use them for?
What Else Could Container Queries‚Ä¶ Query? originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: What Else Could Container Queries‚Ä¶ Query?

articles.author: Preethi
articles.description:
It‚Äôs not that hard to do! Preethi shows you how it's really the same old animation you‚Äôre used to writing in CSS, only applied on a view timeline instead of a normal timeline.
Creating Scroll-Based Animations¬†in Full view() originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Creating Scroll-Based Animations¬†in Full view()

articles.author: Ryan Trimble
articles.description:
The Chrome Dev Team recaps the new CSS features that shipped in Google Chrome this past year in one amazingly designed webpage. They cover new functionality for creating more customizable components, next-gen interactions, and optimizing ergonomics.
We‚Äôve ‚Ä¶
CSS Wrapped 2025 originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: CSS Wrapped 2025

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
The Chrome team recently prototyped a working solution for fitting text to the width of a container in CSS using a text-grow property.
Fit width text in 1 line of CSS originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Fit width text in 1 line of CSS

articles.author: Kevine Nzapdi
articles.description:
I would like to tell you what I learned from a five-year old child about HTML and CSS. It‚Äôs funny how explaining something you do almost naturally teaches you about yourself and what you take for granted.
That Time I Tried Explaining HTML and CSS to My 5-Year Old Niece originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: That Time I Tried Explaining HTML and CSS to My 5-Year Old Niece

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
It's easy to think of HTML Web Components as a recent feature, but it has roots that go all the way back to 1998.
HTML Web Components Proposal From 1998 originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: HTML Web Components Proposal From 1998

articles.author: Andy Clarke
articles.description:
A good measure makes reading text comfortable, while a bad one makes it more difficult. So, rather than allowing layout to dictate the measure, doesn‚Äôt it make more sense for the measure to inform layout decisions?
Getting Creative With ‚ÄúThe Measure‚Äù originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Getting Creative With ‚ÄúThe Measure‚Äù

sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine ‚Äî For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Paul Boag)
articles.description: Turn scattered user research into AI-powered personas that give anyone consolidated multi-perspective feedback from a single question.
articles.title: Giving Users A Voice Through Virtual Personas

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: Meet TARS ‚Äî a simple, repeatable, and meaningful UX metric designed specifically to track the performance of product features. Upcoming part of the Measure UX & Design Impact (use the code üéü IMPACT to save 20% off today).
articles.title: How To Measure The Impact Of Features

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Andy Clarke)
articles.description: In this article, pioneering author and web designer [Andy Clarke](https://stuffandnonsense.co.uk) shows his techniques for creating [Toon Text titles](https://stuffandnonsense.co.uk/toon-text/index.html) using modern CSS and SVG.
articles.title: Smashing Animations Part 7: Recreating Toon Text With CSS And SVG

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Ari Stiles)
articles.description: We‚Äôve got exciting news! eBook versions of ‚ÄúAccessible UX Research,‚Äù a new Smashing Book by Michele A. Williams, are now available for download! Which means soon the book will go to the printer. Order the eBook for instant download now or reserve your print copy at the presale price.
articles.title: Accessible UX Research, eBook Now Available For Download

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Brecht De Ruyte)
articles.description: CSS Wrapped 2025 is out! We‚Äôre entering a world where CSS can increasingly handle logic, state, and complex interactions once reserved for JavaScript. Here is an unpacking of the standout highlights and how they connect to the bigger evolution of modern CSS.
articles.title: State, Logic, And Native Power: CSS Wrapped 2025

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Paul Boag)
articles.description: Lead your organization‚Äôs AI strategy before someone else defines it for you. A practical framework for UX professionals to shape AI implementation.
articles.title: How UX Professionals Can Lead AI Strategy

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Victor Yocco)
articles.description: Explainable AI isn‚Äôt just a challenge for data scientists. It‚Äôs also a design challenge and a core pillar of trustworthy, effective AI products. Victor Yocco offers practical guidance and design patterns for building explainability into real products.
articles.title: Beyond The Black Box: Practical XAI For UX Practitioners

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Patrick Brosset)
articles.description: CSS Masonry is almost here! Patrick Brosset takes a deep dive into what this long-awaited feature means for web developers and how you could make use of it in your own work.
articles.title: Masonry: Things You Won‚Äôt Need A Library For Anymore

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: With December just around the corner, how about some new desktop wallpapers to welcome the last month of the year ‚Äî and the holiday season, if you‚Äôre celebrating? Our latest edition of monthly wallpapers has got you covered. Enjoy!
articles.title: A Sparkle Of December Magic (2025 Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Eleanor Hecks)
articles.description: CAPTCHAs were meant to keep bots out, but too often, they lock people with disabilities out, too. From image classification to click-based tests, many ‚Äúhuman checks‚Äù are anything but inclusive. There‚Äôs no universal solution, but understanding real user needs is where accessibility truly starts.
articles.title: The Accessibility Problem With Authentication Methods Like CAPTCHA

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Ari Stiles)
articles.description: We‚Äôre so happy to announce that ‚ÄúMaturing Design Systems‚Äù‚Äîa Smashing book by Ben Callahan ‚Äî will soon be joining the Smashing Library! Ben‚Äôs insights and advice are so powerful, we thought you might like to read an excerpt from the book. Subscribe to our Smashing newsletter to be notified when orders are open.
articles.title: Design System Culture: What It Is And Why It Matters (Excerpt)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: Practical guidelines on designing time-critical products that prevent errors and improve accuracy. Part of the Measure UX & Design Impact (use the code üéü IMPACT to save 20% off today). With a live UX training starting next week.
articles.title: Designing For Stress And Emergency

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Amit Sheen)
articles.description: Animations can be one of the most joyful parts of building interfaces, but without structure, they can also become one of the biggest sources of frustration. By consolidating and standardizing keyframes, you take something that is usually messy and hard to manage and turn it into a clear, predictable system.
articles.title: Keyframes Tokens: Standardizing Animation Across Projects

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Mansoor Ahmed Khan)
articles.description: Server chaos doesn‚Äôt have to be the norm. AI-ready infrastructure and automation can bring clarity, performance, and focus back to your web work.
articles.title: From Chaos To Clarity: Simplifying Server Management With AI And Automation

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Godstime Aburu)
articles.description: Debugging controllers can be a real pain. Here‚Äôs a deep dive into how CSS helps clean it up and how to build a reusable visual debugger for your own projects.
articles.title: CSS Gamepad API Visual Debugging With CSS Layers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Bryan Rasmussen)
articles.description: There are many existing web features and technologies in the wild that you may never touch directly in your day-to-day work. Perhaps you‚Äôre fairly new to web development and are simply unaware of them because you‚Äôre steeped in the abstraction of a specific framework that doesn‚Äôt require you to know it deeply, or even at all. Bryan Rasmussen looks specifically at XPath and demonstrates how it can be used alongside CSS to query elements.
articles.title: Older Tech In The Browser Stack

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Matt Zeunert)
articles.description: There are lots of tips for [improving your website performance](https://www.debugbear.com/blog/improve-website-performance?utm_campaign=sm-10). But even if you follow all of the advice, are you able to maintain an optimized site? And are you targeting the right pages? Matt Zeunert outlines an effective strategy for web performance optimization and explains the roles that different types of data play in it.
articles.title: Effectively Monitoring Web Performance

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Andy Clarke)
articles.description: SVG is one of those web technologies that‚Äôs both elegant and, at times, infuriating. In this article, pioneering author and web designer Andy Clarke explains his technique for animating SVG elements that are hidden in the Shadow DOM.
articles.title: Smashing Animations Part 6: Magnificent SVGs¬†With `<use>`¬†And CSS Custom Properties

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: Let‚Äôs dive into the building blocks of UX strategy and see how it speaks the language of product and business strategy to create user value while achieving company goals. Part of the Measure UX & Design Impact (use the code üéü IMPACT to save 20% off today).
articles.title: Six Key Components of UX Strategy

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Daniel Schwarz)
articles.description: With component variants, design systems become more flexible, letting you reuse the same component while adapting its look or state with ease. In this article, Daniel Schwarz demonstrates how design tokens can be leveraged to manage components and their variations using Penpot, the open-source tool built for scalable, consistent design.
articles.title: How To Leverage Component Variants In Penpot

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: The new month is just around the corner, and that means: It‚Äôs time for some new desktop wallpapers! All of them are designed by the community for the community and can be downloaded for free. Enjoy!
articles.title: Fading Light And Falling Leaves (November 2025 Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Mat Marquis)
articles.description: Here is a lesson on Iterators. Iterables implement the iterable iteration interface, and iterators implement the iterator iteration interface. Sounds confusing? Mat breaks it all down in the article.
articles.title: JavaScript For Everyone: Iterators

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Andy Clarke)
articles.description: Motion can be tricky: too much distracts, too little feels flat. Ambient animations sit in the middle. They‚Äôre subtle, slow-moving details that add atmosphere without stealing the show. In part two of his series, web design pioneer Andy Clarke shows how ambient animations can add personality to any website design.
articles.title: Ambient Animations In Web Design: Practical Applications (Part 2)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Paul Boag)
articles.description: A simple but powerful mental model for working with AI: treat it like an enthusiastic intern with no real-world experience. Paul Boag shares lessons learned from real client projects across user research, design, development, and content creation.
articles.title: AI In UX: Achieve More With Less

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: Research isn‚Äôt everything. Facts alone don‚Äôt win arguments, but powerful stories do. Here‚Äôs how to turn your research into narratives that inspire trust and influence decisions.
articles.title: How To Make Your UX Research Hard To Ignore

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Frederick O‚ÄôBrien)
articles.description: From A/B tests to AI slop, the modern web is bleeding out its colour. Standardized, templated, and overoptimized, it‚Äôs starting to feel like a digital Levittown. But it doesn‚Äôt have to be.
articles.title: The Grayscale Problem

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Andy Clarke)
articles.description: SVGs, they scale, yes, but how else can you make them adapt even better to several screen sizes? Web design pioneer Andy Clarke explains how he builds what he calls ‚Äúadaptive SVGs‚Äù using ``, ``, and CSS Media Queries.
articles.title: Smashing Animations Part 5: Building Adaptive SVGs With `<symbol>`, `<use>`, And CSS Media Queries

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Yegor Gilyov)
articles.description: Ready to move beyond static mockups? Here is a practical, step-by-step guide to Intent Prototyping ‚Äî a disciplined method that uses AI to turn your design intent (UI sketches, conceptual models, and user flows) directly into a live prototype, making it your primary canvas for ideation.
articles.title: Intent Prototyping: A Practical Guide To Building With Clarity (Part 2)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: How about some new wallpapers to get your desktop ready for fall and the upcoming Halloween season? We‚Äôve got you covered! Following our monthly tradition, the wallpapers in this post were created with love by the community for the community and can be downloaded for free. Enjoy!
articles.title: Shades Of October (2025 Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Lyndon Cerejo)
articles.description: What if your best AI prompts didn‚Äôt disappear into your unorganized chat history, but came back tomorrow as a reliable assistant? In this article, you‚Äôll learn how to turn one-off ‚Äúaha‚Äù prompts into reusable assistants that are tailored to your audience, grounded in your knowledge, and consistent every time, saving you (and your team) from typing the same 448-word prompt ever again.
articles.title: From Prompt To Partner: Designing Your Custom AI Assistant

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Yegor Gilyov)
articles.description: Yegor Gilyov examines the problem of over-reliance on static high-fidelity mockups, which often leave the conceptual model and user flows dangerously underdeveloped. He then explores whether AI-powered prototyping is the answer, questioning whether the path forward is the popular ‚Äúvibe coding‚Äù approach or a more structured, intent-driven approach.
articles.title: Intent Prototyping: The Allure And Danger Of Pure Vibe Coding In Enterprise UX (Part 1)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Andy Clarke)
articles.description: Creating motion can be tricky. Too much and it‚Äôs distracting. Too little and a design feels flat. Ambient animations are the middle ground ‚Äî subtle, slow-moving details that add atmosphere without stealing the show. In this article, web design pioneer Andy Clarke introduces the concept of ambient animations and explains how to implement them.
articles.title: Ambient¬†Animations¬†In¬†Web Design: Principles And Implementation (Part¬†1)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Victor Yocco)
articles.description: With digital products moving to incorporate generative and agentic AI at an increasingly frequent rate, trust has become the invisible user interface. When it works, interactions feel seamless. When it fails, the entire experience collapses. But trust isn‚Äôt mystical. It can be understood, measured, and designed for. Here are practical methods and strategies for designing more trustworthy and ethical AI systems.
articles.title: The Psychology Of Trust In AI: A Guide To Measuring And Designing For User Confidence

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (James Chudley)
articles.description: As responsible digital professionals, we are becoming increasingly aware of the environmental impact of our work and need to find effective and pragmatic ways to reduce it. James Chudley shares a new decarbonising approach that will help you to minimise the environmental impact of your website, benefiting people, profit, purpose, performance, and the planet.
articles.title: How To Minimize The Environmental Impact Of Your Website

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Preethi Sam)
articles.description: From competitive SEO research and monitoring prices to training AI and parsing local geographic data, real-time search results power smarter apps. Tools like SerpApi make it easy to pull, customize, and integrate this data directly into your app or website.
articles.title: SerpApi: A Complete API For Fetching Search Engine Data

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Paul Boag)
articles.description: For too long, personas have been created with considerable effort, only to offer limited value. Paul Boag shows how to breathe new life into this stale UX asset and demonstrates that it‚Äôs possible to create truly useful functional personas in a lightweight way.
articles.title: Functional Personas With AI: A Lean, Practical Workflow

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Marius Sarca)
articles.description: Elastic and bounce effects have long been among the most desirable but time-consuming techniques in motion design. Expressive Animator streamlines the process, making it possible to produce lively animations in seconds, bypassing the tedious work of manual keyframe editing.
articles.title: Creating Elastic And Bounce Effects With Expressive Animator

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Karan Rawal)
articles.description: Real-time dashboards are decision assistants, not passive displays. In environments like fleet management, healthcare, and operations, the cost of a delay or misstep is high. Karan Rawal explores strategic UX patterns that shorten time-to-decision, reduce cognitive overload, and make live systems trustworthy.
articles.title: From Data To Decisions: UX Strategies For Real-Time Dashboards

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Victor Ayomipo)
articles.description: The idea behind this is to share a full, unfiltered look at integrating CSS Cascade Layers into an existing legacy codebase. In practice, it‚Äôs about refactoring existing CSS to use cascade layers without breaking anything.
articles.title: Integrating CSS Cascade Layers To An Existing Project

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Milan Balaƒá)
articles.description: After covering in detail the underlying interaction paradigms of TV experiences in [Part 1](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2025/08/designing-tv-evergreen-pattern-shapes-tv-experiences/), it‚Äôs time to get practical. In the second part of the series, you‚Äôll explore the building blocks of the ‚Äú10-foot experience‚Äù and how to best utilise them in your designs.
articles.title: Designing For TV: Principles, Patterns And Practical Guidance (Part 2)

articles.description: Recently, I wanted to understand how smart home devices actually work. When you scan a QR code and a light appears in your Home app, what's really happening? When you tap "on", what bytes travel across your network? The best way I know to understand...
